name: Luciano Floridi
background: Italian-British philosopher (b. 1964, Rome). Founding Director of Yale Digital Ethics Center; Professor of Cognitive Science at Yale and Sociology of Culture/Communication at University of Bologna. Pioneer of Philosophy of Information (PI), treating information as ontological primitive. Key works: The Philosophy of Information (2011), The Ethics of Information (2013), The Fourth Revolution (2014), The Onlife Manifesto (2015). Most cited living philosopher (Scopus 2020). Focuses on digital ethics, infosphere, onlife.

principles.name: Information Quality
principles.description: Information must be well-formed, meaningful, truthful; curation essential in abundance.
principles.falsification: When information quality leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Infosphere Integrity
principles.description: All information entities (data, systems) have moral standing; protect from entropy (corruption, scarcity) as ethical imperative.
principles.falsification: When infosphere integrity leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Levels of Abstraction (LoA)
principles.description: Analyze phenomena at appropriate abstraction levels (syntactic, semantic, pragmatic) for ethical design.
principles.falsification: When levels of abstraction (loa) leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Onlife Ethics
principles.description: Hyperconnectivity blurs online/offline; holistic ethics for blended reality, privacy, agency.
principles.falsification: When onlife ethics leads to worse outcomes than alternatives
